SPECTRUM FIELD SERVICE INC.
VELMA GAS PLANT
Risk Management Plan
Executive


ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

The Spectrum Field Services Velma Gas Plant has a long-standing commitment to workers and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our process.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Spectrum Field Services plant is located one mile west of Velma Oklahoma, on old highway 7 and operates a variety of process to produce the following petroleum products:
1. Y grade mixture from natural gas
2. Regulated flammable products;
a. Propane   
b. Butane
c. Ethane
d. Methane
e. Pentane
f. IsoPentane
g. IsoButane

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS

The worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with a release of flammable substance(s) at Velma Gas Plant is a vapor cloud explosion involving 212,655 pound of flammable mixture contained in three vessels.  The entire inventory is assumed to release and ignite, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  Since the facility is located in a populated area, the WCS could affect offsite endpoints and nearby public receptors.  Although we have numerous controls to prevent such release and to manage their consequence, Passive Mitigation measures include an Automated plant shutdown system to shut down all engines, plant utilities and actuate valves to their fail-safe position, diverting all incoming gas to the emergence flare.  This complete process will take at minimum 5 seconds.

The alternative release scenario (ARS) for flammable subs

tance at Velma Gas Plant is a vapor cloud explosion resulting from the release of a flammable mixture from closed drain piping (48,627 pound release in 15 minutes).  The release is expected to be isolated by plant operation personnel with 15 minutes or by automated plant shutdown system to shut down all engines, plant utilities and actuate valves to their fail-safe position, diverting all incoming gas to the emergence flare.  This complete process will take at minimum 5 seconds.
Since this facility is located in a populated area, the ARS could affect offsite endpoints or nearby public receptors. This event was selected as being a practical scenario for use in emergency planning.

GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Employee Participation

Spectrum Field Services encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention as follows:  
1. Updating, compiling technical documents, and chemical information, 
2. Performing necessary calculations for PSM and RMP
3.  Maintaining good engineering practices,
4.  Participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team.
  Employees have access to all information pertaining to accident prevention program (Safety Program).





Process Safety Information

Spectrum Field Services Velma Gas Plant keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  These technical documents address the following:
a. Chemical properties, and associated hazards,
b. Necessary Block Flow diagrams of the process,
c.  Maximum intended inventories
d. Upper & Lower Limits of process fixed and rotating equipment,
e. Equipment design basis and configuration information,
f. Identification of all necessary Regulatory equipment design documents, and
g. Sufficient information to assure good engineering practices.
 The location of the technical documents referenced above is listed in the Process Safety Information portion of the PSM. 

Chemical-specif

ic information, including hazard and emergency response/exposure considerations, is provided in material safety data sheet (MSDS).  For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters such as temperatures, level, composition, in the operator?s procedures manual.  The facility maintains the process within these limits by using processes controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems.

The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature, and electrical ratings.  This information, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provides a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes so safety features in the process are not compromised. 


Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

Velma Plant has a comprehensive program to identify and control hazards associated with the RMP covered processes.  This process is systematically examined for potential hazards, and identifies the hazards, puts controls in place to manage the hazards, and recommends additional controls, as appropriate.

Hazard operability studies (HAZOP), are conducted using a team of Velma?s employees who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise.  The team identifies, evaluates, and makes recommendation to management of potential hazards identified.  The team finding is forwarded to Velma?s Management for resolution.  Implementations of mitigation options in response to PHA finding are based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team.  The approved mitigation options in response to PHA team finding are tracked until they are completed.  The final resolution of each finding is documented an

d retained.

The facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating.  The results and finding from these updates are documented and retained.  

Operating Procedures

Spectrum Field Services Velma Gas Plant maintains a written Operating Procedure of the covered process that addresses primary operations mandated by OSHA, EPA, Good Engineering practice, and manufactures.   These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate by management.  The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary by employee?s suggestion, compliance audit, PHAs, Good Engineering practice, Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) and implemented through Management of Change.   
Covered Process Operating procedures are readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job task and maintain the covered process unit operating within its safe limits.

Training

Velma Gas Plant has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the covered process.  New employees receive basic training in process operations if they are not already familiar with such operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  A performance review and written test specific to the facility operations is administered and must be successfully completed during this training period.  After the operator, demonstrates adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are allowed to work independently.  In addition, all operators periodically recei

ve refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years, or more frequently upon request.  All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify /demonstrate skills.


Contractors

Velma Gas Plant uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near Cover Process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors:
1. Perform their work in a safe manner
2. Have the appropriate knowledge and skills
3. Are aware of the hazards in their workplace
4. Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency
5. Understand and follow site safety rules
6. Inform facility personnel of any hazard that they find during their work

This is accomplished by providing contractors with
1. A process overview
2. Information about safety and health hazards
3. Emergency response plan requirements and 
4. Safe work practices before beginning work.

In addition, Velma Gas Plant Management will evaluate the contractor safety program and performance during the selection of a contractor.  Facility personnel periodically monitor contractor performance with regard to their safety obligations.


Pre-Start Safety Review

Spectrum Field Services, Velma Gas plant conducts a PSSR for any new facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to see that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check that construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as quality assurance verification that ac

cident prevention program (Safety Program) requirements are properly implemented. 

Mechanical Integrity

Velma has established practices, procedures for the safe operation of fixed, rotating, and emergency shutdown equipment.  The basic aspects of the program included but not limited to the following:

1. Conducting training,
2. Developing written procedures,
3. Performing inspections and tests,
4. Correcting identified deficiencies,
5. Applying quality assurance measures.

In combination, these activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process.

Maintenance personnel receive training on  
1.    Overview of the process,
2.     Safety and Health hazards,
3.     Applicable maintenance procedures,
4.     Emergency response plan and,
5.    Applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.

Written procedures provide that work is preformed in a consistent manner and serve as a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are preformed to help verify that equipment function as intended and that equipment is within acceptable limits.  If a deficiency is identified and the situation presents an immediate safety concern, the deficiency is corrected before placing the equipment back into service.  A management of change team will review the use of equipment and determine what action is necessary.

An integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  Velma Gas Plant incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps determine that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. 

Safe Work Practices

Velma Gas Plant has long ? standing safe work practices mandated by OSHA?s, EPA?s, Industrial Standards, and Good Engineering Practice in place to help provide employee, public and process safety. 

Management of Change

Velma Gas Plant has a comprehensive system to manage cha

nges to all Reported Covered Processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology, and procedures be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to:
1. Determine that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards,
2. Verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the proposed change.

Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are trained on the changes.


Incident Investigation

Velma Gas Plants promptly investigates all incidents related to a covered process that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective action to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its finding, develops recommendations to prevent occurrence, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team?s finding and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years.

Compliance Audits.

At least Every 3 years a Compliance audit addressing all OSHA, EPA, RMP and Good Engineer Practices, are conducted by employees and Management of Velma Gas Plant.  This audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team?s finding are tracked until they are completed.  Final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.


Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The following is a description of exis

ting features applicable to prevention of accidental release of regulated substances in this facility.

Universal Prevention Activities  

Velma?s Accident release prevention and response polices is applied to all RMP-covered process.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features

Site specific detection and control equipment (safety features) are deployed throughout the plant to:
1. Contain/Control a release,
2. Quickly detect a release and
3. Reduce the consequences of an RMP- regulated substance release.


The Following type of safety features are used in the covered process

 Release Detection
 
1. Hydrocarbon and hydrogen sulfide detectors with alarms


Release Containment/control

1. Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
2. Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process
3. Automated plant shutdown system to shut down all engines, plant utilities and automatically operate all automatic valves to their fail-safe position.  Diverting all incoming gas to the emergence flare.  This complete process will take at minimum of 5 seconds.
4. Curbing or diking to contain liquids releases
5. Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup fire water pumps.)
6. Atmospheric relief devices

Release Mitigation

1. Fire suppression and extinguishing system.
2. Trained emergency response personnel,
3. Personal protective equipment,
4. Blast-resistant building to help protect control systems and personnel.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Velma Gas Plant has an excellent record of accident prevention over the past 5 years.  There has been no RMP- regulated substance release during this period.  The following summarizes of the number of incidents that have occurred during the past 5 years which had onsite or offsite ef

fects.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION


Spectrum Field Services Velma Plant is a NON-RESPONDING FACILITY as per 48 CFR 68.90(b).  The Plant maintains a written emergency action plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment.  The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.

Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed by employees who remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate.

Velma Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police and Sheriff?s Office). This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition, Spectrum Field Services Velma Gas Plant conducts periodic emergency drills and annual refresher training for plant personal.
